DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration, under mounting pressure to increase the pace of its savings and loan bailout, will tell regulators to start immediately on the huge task of selling more than $300 billion in S&L assets. A strategic plan developed by the Resolution Trust Corp. Oversight Board directs regulators to begin selling real estate and other assets even before the government officially closes the S&Ls owning the assets. A copy of the plan was obtained Monday by The Associated Press.

The nation's Big Three automakers are slashing January production and laying off more than 107,000 workers as they struggle with shrinking demand. Most of the layoffs, some of which were announced Monday, will come during the first two weeks of 1990 as traditional Christmas breaks are extended. __ NEW YORK (AP) _ Former stock speculator Salim B. Lewis was spared a prison term for stock manipulation by a federal judge who ordered him to work in a drug rehabilitation clinic, saying ``your skills should not be wasted.'' Lewis, a prominent Wall Street veteran whose downfall resulted indirectly from the Ivan Boesky insider trading scandal, was placed on three years of probation and fined $250,000 Monday after pleading guilty to three counts for illegally inflating the price of Fireman's Fund Corp. stock in May 1986.

Marriott Corp., deciding to concentrate on its flourishing hotel and service divisions, announced a restructuring that calls for the sale of its weaker fast-food and family restaurant divisions. The nation's largest hotel company also said Monday it would reorganize its corporate staff, laying off an as-yet undetermined number of workers, and buy back 10 million of its shares. Marriott said the restructuring would result in as much as $325 million in pre-tax charges against its fourth-quarter earnings.

Reviving a plan to shrink operations by about a third, Eastern Airlines told creditors it expects to sell its prized Latin American routes and projected a net loss of $250 million for the fourth quarter. At a meeting Monday in New York, Eastern officials presented major creditors with a revised business plan that takes into account the sale of the Latin American routes. The plan reverts to an April proposal for restructuring Eastern at about two-thirds its pre-strike size. With the Latin American routes, the airline would have remained 80 percent to 90 percent of its original size.

Arctic temperatures in the nation's midsection are boosting last-minute holiday travel to warmer climes during the peak Christmas and New Year's season, and airlines have aided the cold-weather flight by lifting advance-purchase requirements, travel agents said. The agents said Monday a trend to shorter vacations that can be booked with short notice has been encouraged by the recent cold weather in much of the country.

Securities and Exchange Commission Chairman Richard C. Breeden said he is creating an International Affairs office, going to Japan next month and worrying about inter-agency squabbles over new financial products because of increasing internationalization of securities markets. Breeden announced the new office at a news conference Monday where he reported on cooperative agreements reached last week with securities regulators in France and the Netherlands.

The European Community, angered by U.S. efforts to circumvent a ban on hormone-treated beef, has asked the United States to slash retaliatory duties imposed in the trade dispute. An official said Monday the 12-nation trading bloc wants the tariffs reduced because of legislation requiring U.S. commissaries in Europe to buy their beef from American _ not European _ producers. Commissaries are stores for U.S. military and other personnel.

Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze signed a far-reaching trade agreement with the European Community, a major step toward getting needed Western help for his nation's ailing economy. Shevardnadze, who signed the agreement Monday, called the 10-year accord _ the first between Moscow and the 12-nation trading bloc _ ``truly innovative.''

The stock market took its sharpest drop in five weeks Monday, sending the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials down 42.02 to 2,697.53, its biggest single-day loss since it dropped 47.34 points on Nov. 6. The dollar was mixed in lackluster trdaing. Bond prices finished mostly higher. Heating oil and oter energy futures prices soared; precious metals were lower; livestock futures were mixed; and grains and soybeans were mostly lower.
